principles.name: Segmentation
examples: Divide an organisation into different product centres
Autonomous profit centres
Use a work breakdown structure for a large project
Franchise outlets
Image/Value/Satisfaction segmentation of customer purchase related preferences
Kano Diagram – Excitement, Performance, and Threshold product attribute parameters
Marketing segmentation by demographics, sociographics, psychographics, lifestyles (creation of ‘micro-niches’)
Segmentation of ‘idea management’ process into Fertilization, Seeding, and Incubation phases
SWOT analysis
Min Basadur 8 step ‘Simplex’ innovation process
Flexible pensions
Use of temporary workers on short-term projects
Flexible Manufacturing Systems
Modular furniture/offices
Container shipment
Quality Circles
‘Empowerment’ – segmentation of decision making
Distance learning
Virtual office/remote working
‘Creative Segmentation’ (e.g. high performance small car, easy to use SLR, cordless power tool)

principles.name: Taking Out
examples: Breakdown barriers between departments (Deming’s Fourteen Points)
Eliminate exhortations
Eliminate targets
Drive Out Fear
‘Separate the PEOPLE from the PROBLEM’
‘Lean Manufacture’
USP advertising
Just-In-Time inventory management
Activity-Based Costing instead of allocation cost accounting
Separate development and production activities (skunkworks, tiger-teams)
‘The optimum committee has no members’

principles.name: Local Quality
examples: Moves away from rigid salary structures/job grading
Flexible working hours
Franchise fast food outlets have local dishes in addition to normal product range
Casual (‘dress-down’) days
Introduce ‘Corporate Jester’ to encourage out-of-the-box thinking
Red team/Blue team proposal preparation structures
‘Quiet’ work areas
‘Empowerment’ of individuals
Customised workplaces tailored to ergonomic and psychological needs
Working hours phased for international, shifted time-zone projects
Customisable software
Organisational division by function rather than product
Staff specialists in centres of excellence
Position factory or distribution centre near customers
Hire local people to acquire cultural knowledge
‘Kids areas’ in restaurants

principles.name: Asymmetry
examples: Use a different marketing approach for each client class
Budget for different departments individually rather than using a constant percentage
Skewed normal distributions
Proportionately more ‘P’ or more ‘S’ in the Deming PDSA cycle
360° appraisals
More equitable two-way dialogue between management and workers
Shift away from calendar-influenced sales bias
The Peter Pyramid
Honda’s 4M – ‘man maximum, machine minimum’ product design philosophy

principles.name: Merging
examples: Personal computers in a network
Cell-based Manufacture
Toyota JIT
Merge companies with related products
Internet Cafe
The ‘Joiner Triangle’ – Quality/Scientific Approach/All-One-Team
‘Young engineers have ideas, old engineers have bad experiences’
Theory of Constraints
Enlist customer help in designing the product (e.g. Boeing 777 ‘Working Together Teams’)
Multi-media presentations
‘Aligned, Creative and Exploring’ Teams

principles.name: Universality
examples: Multi-skilling of the workforce
Team leader acts as recorder and timekeeper
‘One-stop shopping’ – supermarkets selling multiple services (insurance, banking, fuel, newspapers, etc.)
Rapid Reaction Forces in the military
Semco – managerial staff set their own salaries and shopfloor workers set their own productivity targets

principles.name: Nested Doll
examples: Store-in-store
Mapping priority innovation areas
Four levels of knowledge contained in effective company training schemes
Hierarchy of employee needs (Basic, Environment, Simple Individual, Complex Individual, Transcendent)
Plug holes in organisation structure
Use ‘Why, What’s Stopping?’ question sequence to get to root causes
Expose traditionally inward-facing job-holders to external events/customers
Door sensors to count customers entering/exiting
Casino hotel architecture (forcing guests to pass through different areas)

principles.name: Anti-Weight
examples: In a merger, one company ‘lifts’ the other with its stronger features (distribution, marketing, methods, capital)
Companies boost sales by connecting with rising products (e.g. movie tie-ins)
A quote on maintaining a depressed stance for psychological impact (Charlie Brown)
A small company is lifted by a resource (e.g. transportation network)
Political parties boost poll ratings by attaching to popular causes
Attach product/service marketing to customer and business driving forces (megatrends like aging population, flexibility, simplicity)

principles.name: Preliminary Anti-Action
examples: When making a public announcement, include all information (as in the Tylenol tampering case)
Use formal risk assessment methods to quantify risk and identify mitigation actions
Customer trials/segmented launch of high-risk products
Use voluntary redundancy, pay-cuts, short-time working, or job-sharing as alternatives to downsizing
Prepare compensation, outplacement, and communication packages prior to layoffs
Epson product development engineers work as sales then service before product development
‘In me the tiger sniffs the rose’ (Siegfried Sassoon)

principles.name: Preliminary Action
examples: Project pre-planning
Perform non-critical path tasks early
Dialogue with employees before embarking on BPR/change management
Use ‘story-boarding’ to facilitate creative problem solving
Kanban arrangements in a Just-In-Time factory
Cell-based manufacture
Publish an agenda before meetings
‘If I had 8 hours to chop down a tree, I’d spend 6 hours sharpening my axe’
Benetton ‘retarded differentiation’ (clothing is knitted before dyed)
Dealer-fit car accessories (e.g. CD player, alloy wheels, air-conditioning)

principles.name: Beforehand Cushioning
examples: Contingency planning
Establish a worst-case fallback position prior to negotiation (‘Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement’)
Back up computer data
Run anti-virus software frequently and update it
Encourage short, effective meetings by removing chairs
Include arbitration/mediation clauses in contracts
Begin with ‘S’ in the PDSA cycle
‘80% of a successful production is in the casting’ (Lindsay Anderson)

principles.name: Equipotentiality
examples: Make ‘horizontal’ career changes to broaden skills
Team members distribute their own merit award money
Use Force-Field Analysis for teambuilding and problem solving
Beware of the Peter Principle (‘Every employee tends to rise to his/her level of incompetence’)

principles.name: The Other Way Round
examples: Bring the mountain to Mohammed instead of vice versa
Expansion instead of contraction during recession
Benchmark against the worst instead of the best
Blame the process, not the person
Quote: ‘Anyone doing anything weird wasn’t weird at all’ – Paul McCartney
Home-shopping, home banking, park-and-ride schemes
‘If you obey all the rules, you miss all the fun’ (Katherine Hepburn)

Turn the process ‘upside down’: Cash-till assistant becomes the focal point; reverse help lines so most qualified staff are first contacted; shift to a product-based organisation; ‘Ready, Fire, Aim’ (Tom Peters); shift from internal to externally focused vision; adopt the Peter Pyramid; embrace corporate unlearning; ‘Nothing fails like success’; ‘We don’t stop playing because we grow old, we grow old because we stop playing’; ‘When you reach the top, that’s when the climb begins’ (Michael Caine)

principles.name: Spheroidality – Curvature
examples: Ergonomic desk/work-station designs
Take the shortest path to the customer – route around the organisation rather than through bureaucracy
‘Form the wagons into a circle’ (John Wayne)
Mobile factory
Mobile car service (mechanic comes to you)
Mobile library
‘Meals on wheels’ / home-delivery pizza
Rotate leadership of a team
Establish a sphere of influence and then market to that sphere
Quality Circles and circular work cells
Organisational charts that resemble a solar system (e.g. Levi Strauss’ IS Department)

principles.name: Dynamics
examples: Empowerment
‘Customer Response Teams’
Continuous Process Improvement
Rapid Reaction Force
Swatch design proliferation for specific market niches
‘Cafeteria’ benefits – employees choose their own insurance, etc.
Embrace constant transitions in a turbulent business environment
Work teams that work at different rates on different objectives
Geographically or functionally independent business units
Conglomerate structures
Gallery Furniture online shopping where customers control cameras remotely
Changing the supervisor’s role to avoid ‘whack-a-mole’ firefighting
Flexible organisation structure (chaocracy)

principles.name: Partial or Excessive Actions
examples: For a new market, use ‘saturation’ advertising by all media (mail, newspapers, local magazines, radio, TV, billboards)
Communicate more often and with more information than necessary
‘If it ain’t broke, improve it anyway’ – Japanese process management philosophy
‘The most important numbers are the ones you’ll never know’ – W.E. Deming
‘Communication is and should be hellfire and sparks, as well as sweetness and light’ – Aman Vivian Rakoff

principles.name: Another Dimension
examples: 360° appraisals
Multi-dimensional organisational hierarchy charts (3D/4D including time, ‘Buckyball Management’)
Distributed responsibility and authority (e.g., quality and safety shared responsibilities)

Multi-story arrangements: Organisational hierarchy; multi-stack storage systems; employees ‘disappear’ and reappear as in a theme park; ‘Pile ‘em high, sell ‘em cheap’; ‘Standing on the shoulders of giants…’
Horizontal (peer) communication; switch from vertical to horizontal (lateral) thinking; shift from line to project management in matrix organisations; shift from portrait to landscape report format
View the organisation from the outside (using consultants, mystery shoppers); adopt new ways of looking at the selling process (e.g., ‘Evergreen Lease’); external benchmarking

principles.name: Mechanical Vibration
examples: Use the catchball process in hoshin planning to set the organisation ‘vibrating’
Leverage conflict constructively (as per Robert Townsend and Margaret J Wheatley)
Communicate frequently in multiple modes (newsletter, intranet, meetings)
Reference a quote from D. Coleman (VP & CFO, Apple)
Use strategic planning (e.g., hoshin Kanri) to set a resonant frequency for breakthrough strategy (‘Kansei’ concept)
Bring new blood into the team; hire consultants

principles.name: Periodic Action
examples: Use periodic or pulsating actions instead of continuous operation: Batch manufacture; tidal traffic flow schemes; change team leadership periodically; introduce sabbaticals

Change periodic magnitude or frequency: Audit at irregular intervals; use monthly or weekly feedback instead of annual reviews; adopt flexible savings schemes with higher interest rates for fewer withdrawals
Use pauses between impulses: Get work done between meetings; perform maintenance during vacations; 24-hour car service operation (evening pick-up and return by breakfast)

principles.name: Continuity of Useful Action
examples: Carry on work continuously: Run bottleneck operations continuously (Theory of Constraints); institute Constant Improvement (Deming’s Fourteen Points); continuous online monitoring; 24-hour operations

Eliminate idle or intermittent actions: Multi-skilling to improve workflow; conduct training during pauses; ‘Hot-tilling’ in supermarkets; life-long learning; ‘The more I practice, the luckier I get’ (Gary Player)

principles.name: Skipping
examples: Conduct processes at high speed: ‘Incrementalism is innovation’s worst enemy’ (Nicholas Negroponte); ‘Don’t be afraid to take a big step if one is indicated. You can’t cross a chasm in two small jumps’ (David Lloyd George); ‘Fail Fast; Learn Fast’; rapid prototyping; ‘If you want to succeed, double your failure rate’ (JR Watson)

principles.name: Blessing in Disguise
examples: Recast an attack on you as an attack on the problem; handle customer complaints in a way that reinforces positive perceptions; use ‘provocations’ to encourage new ideas; ‘The Extra Mile will have no traffic jams’

Eliminate fear of change by introducing fear of competition; assign a ‘problem’ person to a role where they excel; use a loss-leader strategy; implement park-and-ride schemes; force polluting industries to adjust

Amplify a harmful factor so it is no longer harmful: ‘That’s not a bug, it’s a feature’; employ benevolent dictatorship; reduce resourcing to drive innovation; restrict supply to create scarcity value

principles.name: Feedback
examples: Introduce feedback to improve processes: Statistical Process Control (SPC); use budgets as feedback; enlist customers in design; use extranets; customer surveys and seminars; Active Transition Management; electronic bulletin boards; loyalty cards; ‘What you measure is what you get’ (Joe Juran)

If feedback is already used, change its magnitude or influence: Change measures from budget variance to customer satisfaction; expose designers and marketers to customers; employ Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis; use examples like Toshiba’s cross-functional shifts; ‘Open the kimono’; ‘Supravision’; ‘Co-evolutionary marketing’; Motorola ‘open dissent’; use ‘half-life’ as a performance measure

principles.name: Intermediary
examples: Use an intermediary carrier or process: Use an impartial body during difficult negotiations (e.g. ACAS); employ a ‘provocative operator’ (DeBono’s ‘Po’); subcontract non-core business (cleaning, transport); use a franchisee as intermediary; travel agents; UPS distribution systems; KLM ‘feeder’ airline concept; ‘Video Plus’ programme; ‘Cuckoo Investments’

Merge one object temporarily with another: Introduce specialist troubleshooting or firefighting teams; hire consultants; use bridging loan arrangements; subcontract occasional services (accounts, cleaning, transport)

principles.name: Self-Service
examples: Make an object serve itself: Quality Circles; self-help groups; brand image circularity (e.g. Harvard Business School effect); ‘Cookies’ on the Internet; bar-codes in supermarkets

Use waste or lost resources: Re-hire retired workers; loan out under-utilised workers; develop industrial eco-systems; brown-field developments; recycle used containers and packaging; scan mail into data systems and recycle the paper

principles.name: Copying
examples: Use simpler and inexpensive copies: Virtual reality via computer instead of expensive vacations; audiotapes instead of seminars; rapid prototyping (stereolithography); scan rare historic documents so originals are preserved; Lascaux II reproduction of cave paintings

Replace an object or process with optical copies: Virtual product service manuals; video-conferencing instead of travel; central electronic database instead of paper records; web-based personal calendars
If optical copies are used, move to IR or UV: Evaluate employee morale and customer satisfaction using multiple methods; benchmark against competitors
Sustain organization’s trademark, logo, motto, and color identity

principles.name: Cheap Short-Living Objects
examples: Replace an expensive object with multiples of inexpensive objects: Use disposable paper objects; plastic cups in motels; disposable diapers; various medical supplies; use numerical simulation; flight simulator; Swatch ‘renewed impulse’ buying

principles.name: Mechanics Substitution
examples: Replace a mechanical means with a sensory means: Virtual reality via computer; touch screen data entry (e.g. in wedding registries); electronic voting
Use electric, magnetic, and electromagnetic fields to interact with the object

principles.name: Pneumatics and Hydraulics
examples: Use gas and liquid parts instead of solid parts: (Examples include use of ‘breathing spaces’ and fluid system applications)

principles.name: Flexible Shells and Thin Films
examples: Use flexible shells and thin films instead of three-dimensional structures: (Examples include thin-film dielectrics, epitaxy, oxidation, poly-silicon, metallization on planar Si wafers)

Isolate the object from the external environment using flexible shells and thin films: (Examples include thin-film passivation, encapsulation, air gaps with polymer cushioning, cover tape for tape-and-reel)

principles.name: Porous Materials
examples: Make an object porous or add porous elements: (Examples include multi-step air filtration in clean rooms, multipore filters for DI water, polypropylene and carbon filters, porous chucks, metal web baskets)

If already porous, use the pores to introduce a useful substance or function: (Examples include capillary effects for cleaning and chemical treatment in vias and trenches, metal web for screen printing of solder paste, capillary action for solder drawing)

principles.name: Color Changes
examples: Change the color of an object or its environment: Create a strong brand image using bespoke corporate colors; use colors to communicate state of alert (e.g. red, amber, green)

Change the transparency: Make stock inventory transparent for Just-In-Time delivery; use transparent packaging for self-advertising; introduce smoke-screening to disguise confidential activities; switch between transparent and opaque during negotiations
Use colored additives or luminescent elements to improve observability

principles.name: Homogeneity
examples: Make objects interact with a given object of the same material: Hire local people for cultural insight; use the same brand name for a product group; divide customers into homogeneous clusters; include customers in focus groups

principles.name: Discarding and Recovering
examples: Make portions that have fulfilled their functions go away: Subcontract marketing, sales, or advertisement agencies
Conversely, restore consumable parts directly: Use warranty systems to commit to repair or replace failing parts

principles.name: Parameter Changes
examples: Change an object's physical state: Establish virtual shopping; institute online catalogs; telephone banking; electronic voting
Change the concentration or consistency: (Examples not fully detailed)
Change the degree of flexibility: Use special offers for promotions
Change the temperature: Initiate new challenges for the customer service team

Change other parameters: Switch marketing to non-traditional customers; change traditional names (e.g., quality department renamed ‘Customer Satisfaction Team’); sell non-material attributes (e.g., cultural needs, image, self-esteem)

principles.name: Phase Transitions
examples: Use phenomena occurring during phase transitions: S-curve for marketing and sales evolution – different product/service life stages (e.g., ‘Problematic child’, ‘Star’, ‘Milky cow’, ‘Outsider’)

principles.name: Thermal Expansion
examples: Use thermal expansion (or contraction) of materials: (Examples include thermal expansion drive in variable MEMS capacitors)

If used, employ multiple materials with different coefficients: Expand or contract marketing efforts depending on product/service ‘hotness’; include both ‘hard’ and ‘soft’ persons on negotiation teams

principles.name: Boosted Interactions
examples: Replace common air with oxygen-enriched air; replace enriched air with pure oxygen; expose air or oxygen to ionizing radiation; use ionized oxygen; replace ozonized oxygen with ozone
Introduce obsession with customer-perceived quality and desire to delight customers
Hire highly creative individuals who understand ‘The voice of the customer’
Get customers excited about a product or service by giving them ownership of the change
Achieve ‘Wow!’ effect by exceeding customer expectations and providing competitive advantage
Overcome reluctance of dissatisfied customers to complain

principles.name: Inert Atmosphere
examples: Replace a normal environment with an inert one: Arrange anonymous surveys or interviews; use neutral, indifferent tonality in surveys; be aware that customer service/employee indifference leads to customer defection
Add neutral parts or inert additives: Use neutral third parties during difficult negotiations

principles.name: Composite Structures
examples: Change from uniform to composite structures: Combine high risk with low risk marketing strategy; establish multi-disciplinary customer service teams with diverse personality types; employ multi-skilled (‘Renaissance’) people at customer interface positions
